awd_titl_txt: Student Support to 5th International Conference on Phonomic Crystals/Metamaterials, Phonon Transport/Coupling & Topological Phonomics; Tucson, Arizona; 2-7 June 2019
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant provides funds to support 15 graduate students, including those from under-represented groups, to participate in PHONONICS 2019, which is the 5th International Conference on Phononic Crystals/Metamaterials, Phonon Transport/Coupling and Topological Phononics. Activities will include attendance in the conference sessions, presentation of a poster, and participation in (1) evening technical mini-lectures and (2) mini-workshop on career planning and development for young researchers. The mini-lectures will focus on emerging topics in the areas of phononics such as additive manufacturing, computational methods, and topological acoustics and its potential applications. The mini-workshop on career planning and development will help the graduate students to begin to shape their careers.

This project will facilitate the formation of a cohort of graduate students in the multidisciplinary field of acoustic metamaterials and phononic crystals. Furthermore, this project will prepare these students for the leadership in this emerging scientific and technological field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
PHONONICS 2019, the 5th International Conference on Phononic Crystals, Metamaterials, Phonon Transport, Coupling and Topological Phononics was held on the campus of the University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ.  PHONONICS 2019 addressed the challenges and opportunities that promise transformative advancements in knowledge and performance of phononic structures and acoustic metamaterials. The conference also encouraged exchange of innovative and forward-looking scientific and technical ideas as well as exchange of cutting-edge methods and practices. PHONONICS 2019 attracted nearly 200 participants from around the nation and the world. The conference also addressed workforce training and preparedness needed to contribute to an emerging U.S. economy leveraging advanced phononic crystals and acoustic metamaterials. This was done through one evening workshop on professional development open to students, postdocs and young researchers. This grant enabled the participation of 12 young researchers (graduate students, posdoctoral fellows or junior faculty). Participation of these 12 young researchers (many of them from under-represented groups) led to networking opportunities with world leaders in the field, professional development opportunities.  PHONONICS 2019 served as a venue to develop and improve the technical  and professional skills of these 12 participants with the aim of forming the next generation of leaders in the field of phononics crystals and acoustic metamaterials.
